9.40.text:
For much of the nineteenth century, Britain's
settler colonies, the colonies that we now

15.26.text:
call Australia, New Zealand and parts of South
Africa and Canada, were seen by many within

22.46.text:
Britain essentially as dumping grounds for
the poor or perhaps places where disgraced

28.93.text:
minor aristocrats or bucaneering capitalists
could go and make their fortune. They didn't

36.01.text:
feature particularly prominently in the British
political imagination. There had been an attempt

44.43.text:
earlier in the century to try and give a more
positive gloss to settler colonialism, with

50.47.text:
some success, but it was only really in the
last three decades of the nineteenth century

56.02.text:
that settler colonies began to play a much
more positive role in the way that many in

62.69.text:
Britain thought about the empire and world
politics more generally. For some, the settlement

71.54.text:
colonies were merely a continuation of British
society overseas. British ideas, values and

79.25.text:
institutions were simply being transposed
from the so-called motherland to pastures

84.53.text:
new. For others, however, the colonies performed
an almost utopian role. Whilst Britain was

93.95.text:
overcrowded, decaying, mediocre, a country
of industrial slums and satanic mills, the

102.49.text:
frontiers of colonial settlement represented
not just extensions of Britain, but a chance

108.79.text:
to create new forms of political community.
This idea of a Greater Britain, the British

117.03.text:
nation, or the British race as it was sometimes
called, transformed into a global diaspora,

124.62.text:
engaged the imagination of those at both ends
of the political spectrum. We have to remember

132.73.text:
that places like New Zealand and Australia
were far more progressive in many repects

137.34.text:
politically than Britain was itself. New Zealand
of course famously is the first country in

141.51.text:
the world to give women the vote, the franchise
was much more extensive in all of the colonies

147.98.text:
than it was in Britain. So for working men
in particular for much of the century the

153.34.text:
colonies looked an extremely or potentially
looked an extremely friendly environment in

156.07.text:
which to be based. So its not surprising that
some political radicals and some socialists

161.66.text:
did see Greater Britain as a space in which
a more progressive and more egalitarian politics

167.60.text:
could be enacted and played out, and potentially
even one in which the motherland itself, Great

173.98.text:
Britain, could be democratised from the colonies,
so if we link all the political communities

179.51.text:
together more closely this might have positive
political effects on Britain itself. So that

183.34.text:
was one line of argument, there were plenty
of other socialists and radicals who fundamentally

189.53.text:
opposed Greater Britain seeing it was the
latest iteration of imperialism seeing it

194.09.text:
as negative in all sorts of different ways,
so don't want to suggest that there was a

198.16.text:
single socialist position on this, far from
it. Nevertheless, there was quite significant

203.49.text:
support. Conservatives supported Greater Britain
for very different reasons in many ways. Many

211.56.text:
saw the increasing democratisation of Britain,
slow as it was, and we have to remember that

216.58.text:
it was incredibly slow, as a threat. A threat
in all sorts of ways, as a threat to established

221.29.text:
privileges and hierarchies at home but also
as a threat to the empire itself. And so one

226.92.text:
of their fears was that by giving ever increasing
numbers of men the vote, of course very little

232.44.text:
thought at the time amongst the dominant elites
at least of giving women the vote, but the

237.72.text:
thought was that if we give increasing large
numbers of working men the vote they will

242.13.text:
vote against empire, they will look after
their own interests and that will typically

247.27.text:
involve them either becoming or being ambivalent
about empire or being actively opposed to

252.54.text:
it and so therefore its important to try to
create a Greater Britain which nullifies or

260.57.text:
reduces this possibility. And one way to do
that is to support systematic emigration from

265.78.text:
the cities. Many at the time saw the industrial
slums of Britain's great cities as the threat;

277.43.text:
as breeding grounds for potential socialists.
By encouraging and perhaps funding emigration

284.74.text:
of many poor city dwellers to the colonies
their radical politics could be neutralised.

292.77.text:
It was hoped that the transformation of their
environment, the conditions under which they

297.01.text:
lived, would transform their political views.
The alienated urban working class would become

305.45.text:
rugged, virtuous settlers. Greater Britain
was a very loose term, it was an umbrella

312.54.text:
under which lots of different people could
travel and proselytise their own particular

318.05.text:
political vision. Its one of its strengths
on the one hand and ultimately it was also

324.83.text:
one of its weaknesses, because as it happens
people did tend to end up disagreeing pretty

329.96.text:
heavily on what exactly greater Britain was
and thus what needed to be done to bring about

334.58.text:
and secure it. So at one end of the specturm
you might say it was an incredibly vague and

339.36.text:
amorphous notion where Greater Britain just
referred to the collection of peoples who

344.53.text:
regarded themselves as British in one way
or another, who happened to be spread throughout

348.18.text:
different communities around the world. So
people who supported this vision were keen

352.89.text:
to maintain connections of one kind or another
with British emigrants in Australia and New

357.95.text:
Zealand. They wanted them to be recognised
more positively, they wanted them to be involved

363.96.text:
in all sorts of economic and cultural transactions
but it didn't really involve much more than

368.57.text:
that. At the other end of the spectrum there
are those that saw Greater Britain as potentially

376.00.text:
a global federal state in the making. Most
enthusiasts for Greater Britain were somewhere

386.45.text:
in the middle of these two positions. They
were keen to further develop political links

392.57.text:
between Britain and the settler colonies but
tended to shy away from more radical plans

397.82.text:
that proposed a federal structure to coordinate
the different parts of this new political

403.68.text:
community. Much as they might have wanted
to see a new trans-oceanic state they recognised

413.24.text:
that it was deeply unrealistic within the
current political culture and therefore opted

418.89.text:
for much less ambitious plans. Technology
played a fundamental role in all these different

425.92.text:
conceptions of Greater Britain, so whether
you were a radical federalist or whether you

430.83.text:
believed simply in moderate tinkering with
the existing structure, the fact that new

435.78.text:
communications technologies allowed communication
across great distances instantaneously meant

442.72.text:
that a sense of community, a sense of belonging
could be utilised to reinforce the sense of

449.46.text:
Britishness. So whereas in the eighteenth
century and for much of the nineteenth century

455.14.text:
it would take weeks possibly months to communicate
with people by letter who were accross the

459.69.text:
oceans in Cananda, in South Africa, in New
Zealand, Australia, by the time the electrical

461.99.text:
telegraph reached from Britain to the outposts
of empire, communication was near enough instant.

469.13.text:
And this was seen to fundamentally transform
the conditions of politics, it allowed people

473.33.text:
to imagine themselves as part of a single
political community. Of course many of the

479.09.text:
people who are populating Australia, New Zealand,
South Africa and so on and so forth, are emigrants

484.65.text:
from Britain so they already have very strong
connections with the motherland and this just

488.71.text:
serves to reinforce them, it allows them to
maintain contact with their families and friends

493.39.text:
back home much more easily, it allows them
to read newspapers the day after they were

498.01.text:
printed in London, it allows them to share
in the rituals of national identity and so

503.60.text:
on and so forth. So theres no doubt that it
reinforces an existing set of national affiliations

510.04.text:
to Great Britain, but at the same time there
are complex currents of settler nationalism

516.49.text:
emerging within the colonies. Now nationalist
historians of Australia, New Zealand, Canada

522.11.text:
and so on tended to see this as in significant
tension with or as an antithesis to Britannic

528.17.text:
nationalism, so you get the emergence of a
distinct Australian national identity which

532.04.text:
is defined partly in opposition to being part
of the British empire and that may well happen

536.97.text:
much, much later in the history of empire,
during the middle decades of the twentieth

541.71.text:
century say, but during the closing decades
of the nineteenth and the early decades of

544.88.text:
the twentieth century these two forms of affiliation
went hand in hand, they weren't in tension.

550.18.text:
You could be simultaneously a proud Australian
and a member of the wider British diaspora.

557.33.text:
There were, of course, minorities within the
settler colonies, the French speaking Quebecois

567.94.text:
in Canada or the Irish in Australia, for example,
who were either deeply ambivalent about, or

575.27.text:
resistant to, attempts to impose or deepen
a sense of Britishness. Even so within these

583.58.text:
populations there was occassional support
for being at least part of a grand imperial

589.68.text:
structure. The flexibility of the idea of
Greater Britain, its lack of a precise definition,

600.00.text:
stimulated considerable debate about who was
included in or could become part of this family

607.08.text:
of Britishness. There is for instance great
ambiguity and disagreement about whether the

613.60.text:
United States is or should be part of that
Greater Britain, that Anglo-sphere or again

623.41.text:
sometimes at the time often at the time a
racialised language of Anglo-Saxonism is used.

629.34.text:
So for some people the United States is or
should be part of that global family of Britishness.

637.44.text:
For the some people the quote Anglo-Saxon
Germans ought to be invited into it, remember

644.69.text:
that Cecil Rhodes when he established the
scholarships in Oxford that were going to

649.97.text:
perpetuate his name originally included German
as well as American and British colonial students

658.02.text:
in the scheme. There's lots of doubt and ambiguity
and dispute about whether Ireland and the

663.96.text:
Irish really belong to the family or not,
and fascinatingly though more at the margin

672.18.text:
about whether non-white subjects of the empire
might be or might in future become really

680.97.text:
part of the family. The intensely racialised
discourse of so much of public life in that

687.51.text:
time tended to proclaim or assume that they
weren't, that they couldn't be, this was a

694.01.text:
whites only affair as really in its origins
the commonwealth was. But you do get significant

703.55.text:
numbers especially among educated elites in
most obviously the Caribbean, but also in

711.27.text:
West and Southern Africa, in Bengal and elsewhere
saying we are British too, we are part of

719.26.text:
this Greater Britain, we are part of this
family and we demand the rights which come
